author: albusdompeldorius
content: Hi, I have a question regarding zk-rollups / validiums. From what I understand, the size of the input of a given zk-circuit is fixed. Does this mean that even for validiums (where tx data is not posted on-chain) there is a hardcoded limit of transactions per block? If so, is there any other way to dynamically adjust this limit depending on usage, other than having an upgrade mechanism where the whole circuit can be replaced?

author: treyzania
content: not if you use a recursive snark

author: albusdompeldorius
content: Hmm, wouldn't you still need to encode different sizes of the inner circuit inside the outer circuit?

author: albusdompeldorius
content: Do you mean that you make the inner circuit part of the private input for the outer circuit, and then the outer circuit checks that the inner circuit is an instance of a pre-defined template? Nice.

author: treyzania
content: the "outer" circuit verifies other snark proofs

author: treyzania
content: and then you repeat that and make a tree-looking thing

author: treyzania
content: so the deeper proofs can be computed in parallel, so the asymptotic complexity assuming parallel computation is in the depth of the tree

author: treyzania
content: look at how coda did it

author: treyzania
content: except their leaf circuits verified entire blocks

author: albusdompeldorius
content: Ahh, yeah now I see. That's a really cool way to do it. Thanks!
